Greg Barton wrote:

>...
>
>Similar effects could be attained by genes each consuming a resource
>of some sort.  Members of a species would consume a similar set of
>resources.  If you limit the resources, you limit the size of a
>species' population, and how many agents can search an area of the
>space.  
>
Yes, this approach provides a sort of counter force to the clustering 
generated by speciation. Actually this sort of pattern appears in nature 
if you think about how the various attraction and repulsion forces from 
the sub-atomic to astronomical scale work in unison to keep everything 
in a state of balance.


>This is also another way for species to compete and cooperate
>in complex ways, especially if agents are able to produce resources.
>(Possibly linked to their fitness evaluation.)
>  
>
This would be a mechanism allowing species to define their own degree of 
clustering. I understand this also happens in nature, see this recent 
news article about buterflies that vary the complexity of their wing 
patterns depending on the size of the population they are within, which 
in turn varies who they mate with:

http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/4708459.stm

Regards,

Colin
